com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.gestures

Class GestureDeviceManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.gestures.GestureDeviceManager

  • public class GestureDeviceManager
extends java.lang.Object

    The GestureDeviceManager is responsible for communicating with the gesture device as well as providing listeners with event notifications when gesture events have occured. It will invoke the appropriate listeners when an event has occurred.

    The API will provide classes that expose Camera Gesture functionality and interface classes for callbacks when a gesture event is dispatched. It will also provide functions to control the optional Gestures Overlay Service GUI. The developer can control which elements will be displayed as well as the option to turn off the overlay entirely.

    • The minimum Android API level is 15.
    • The permission android.permission.CAMERA must be set.
    • Not all devices will have Camera Gestures functionality. Query isCameraGestureSupported() to verify. This may also return false if the camera permission android.permission.CAMERA is not set.
    • Not all devices will have the Gestures Overlay Service installed. Query #isFeatureSupported(FEATURE_OVERLAY_SERVICE) to verify.

    Multiple Gesture Modes are supported by the system, but only a single gesture mode can be active at any given time. A Gesture Mode implies a specific approach to interaction with the device. See GestureMode for detailed information regarding the available Gesture Modes.

    Gesture modes can by changed dynamically at runtime by calling the setMode(GestureMode) method with the desired mode. The gesture system will immediately switch to the new mode.

    The default behavior for the SDK is for the system to provide camera frames to the gesture system.

    Multiple activities may use the Camera Gesture SDK.

    Each activity must instantiate its own GestureDeviceManager in order to interface with the Camera Gesture SDK.

    The gesture device will use the settings of the current foreground activity. These settings include mode, overlay preferences, etc.

    For example, Activity 1 has mode set to NEAR_GESTURE and Activity 2 has mode set to ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE. When Activity 1 is in the foreground, the mode is NEAR_GESTURE, and when Activity 2 is in the foreground, the mode is set to ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE.

    Only one activity can be in the foreground at any time.

    Resource management will be handled by GestureDeviceManager. This means that an Activity does not need to notify the GestureDeviceManager on state changes. The GestureDeviceManager is responsible for restoring the state it needs for its application to receive the correct events. (i.e. it will have to restore any modes, etc. every time the Activity lifecycle is onResume()). On the onResume() state, the gesture device starts automatically. On the onPause() state, the gesture device stops automatically. The GestureDevice is the interface to the Gesture Framework.

    The GestureDeviceManager is registered to the calling the lifecycle of the activity and will open/start and stop/close the GestureDevice in the appropriate state. The device will open when onResume() and will close at onPause().

    The device may not contain support for the GestureDevice. The developer must query isCameraGestureSupported() to check if camera gestures are enabled and supported. If there is no camera gesture feature enabled on the device, the function will return false. Invoking any other API calls will not do anything.

    The GestureDeviceManager will also set OverlayPreferences and invoke the overlay when events are received from the GestureDevice. There may or may not be an overlay available. If the service is not available, there will be no visual feedback to the user, but the gesture events will be propagated normally. The developer can query the availability of the Gesture Overlay Service by calling #isFeatureSupported(FEATURE_OVERLAY_SERVICE)

    Development Flow

    The following is the application development flow:

    • Add android.permission.CAMERA permission to AndroidManifest.
    • Query for capability of device. Call isCameraGestureSupported() to check if the device has the camera gesture feature enabled.
    • Create a new GestureDeviceManager object. Optionally, set the desired mode as a parameter within the constructor, otherwise the default constructor will default the mode to GestureMode.OFF (gestures will be disabled).
    • Call #isFeatureSupported(FEATURE_OVERLAY_SERVICE) to check if Overlay Service is installed on the device.
    • If the desired mode has not been set then set the mode when appropriate. This is done by calling the setMode(GestureMode) function. The GestureMode may be changed dynamically without restarting the Application.
    • Optionally, create an OverlayPreferences object to control the overlay preferences. Set the overlay preferences by calling the GestureDeviceManager setOverlayPreferences(OverlayPreferences) method.
    • Register Event Listeners. Event Listeners are interfaces that contain callback methods. These methods will be called by the SDK when a qualifying event has occurred.

    Usage
    The following is a simple sample application. This application is set to use the GestureMode.ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE mode. The OverlayPreferences is set to display engagement, left, and right only. 

    
 // The Class EngageAndSwipeTestApp. This application is set to use the
 // ENGAGMENT_SWIPE mode. The OverlayPreferences is set to display engagement,
 // left, and right only.

 public class EngageAndSwipeTestApp extends Activity implements
         EngagementListener, SwipeListener {

     // The GestureDeviceManager instance.
     private GestureDeviceManager mGestureMgr;

     public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
         super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
         setContentView(R.layout.main);

         if (GestureDeviceManager.isCameraGestureSupported() == false) {
             // Camera Gestures are not available or enabled on this system.
             // No events or visual feedback will be provided.
             // Notify the user.
         }

         // ..if continued...

         // create Gesture manager and set the initial mode.
         mGestureMgr = new GestureDeviceManager(this,
                 GestureMode.ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE);

         if(GestureDeviceManager.isFeatureSupported(FEATURE_OVERLAY_SERVICE)
             == false) { // No default overlay service is
             installed on the system. // Handle visual
             feedback to the user if necessary.
         }

         // setup the overlay preferences
         mGestureMgr.setOverlayPreferences(new OverlayPreferences(true,
                 OverlayPreferences.LEFT | OverlayPreferences.RIGHT
                         | OverlayPreferences.ENGAGEMENT));

         // Set the SwipeListener and Engagement Listener
         mGestureMgr.setSwipeListener(this);
         mGestureMgr.setEngagementListener(this);

     }

     //
     // The following are some of the event handlers.
     //

     public void onLeftSwipe(SwipeEvent e) {
         // Handle the event.
     }

     public void onRightSwipe(SwipeEvent e) {
         // Handle the event.
     }

     public void onUpSwipe(SwipeEvent e) {
         // Handle the event.
     }

     public void onDownSwipe(SwipeEvent e) {
         // Handle the event.
     }

     public void onEngagementChanged(EngagementEvent e) {
         // Handle the event.
     }
 }

      • GestureDeviceManager

        public GestureDeviceManager(Activity appContext)
        Creates a new GestureDeviceManager instance. The mode is default to OFF.
        Parameters:
        appContext - Main Application context.

      • GestureDeviceManager

        public GestureDeviceManager(Activity appContext,
                    GestureMode mode)
                     throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Instantiates a new gesture device manager. The desired GestureMode is set after the GestureDevice is opened.

        The GestureMode can be changed dynamically at run time. The Gesture System will immediately switch to the new mode.

        Parameters:
        appContext - The application context.
        mode - The desired GestureMode configuration.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if android.permission.CAMERA is not set.
        See Also:
        GestureMode

    • Method Detail

      • setMode

        public void setMode(GestureMode mode)
        Sets the mode in the GestureDevice. If the device is not open and ready, the selected mode will be set once the device is started.

        The GestureMode can be changed dynamically at run time. The Gesture System will immediately switch to the new mode.

        Parameters:
        mode - The tracking mode we want.
        See Also:
        GestureMode

        Returns:
        the gesture mode
        See Also:

      • setOverlayPreferences

        public void setOverlayPreferences(OverlayPreferences overlayPrefs)
        Set the gesture overlay parameters. If null is passed in, the default OverlayPrefs will be used. See the @link OverlayPreferences for more detailed information.

        The default preferences is set as enabled and configured to display all arrow icons: left, right, up, and down as well as engagement icon.

        Parameters:
        overlayPrefs - the overlay prefs
        See Also:
        for OverlayPreferences examples

      • getOverlayPreferences

        public OverlayPreferences getOverlayPreferences()
        Gets the overlay preferences. Return null if one has not been set.
        Returns:
        The current OverlayPreferences object or null if one has not been set.

      • setEngagementListener

        public void setEngagementListener(EngagementListener listener)
        Sets a EngagementListener that the GestureDeviceManager can send engagement events to. See EngagementListener.EngagementEvent for more information.

        If null is passed in, engagement events will not longer be sent to the application. If an application has set an engagement listener but is no longer interested in receiving events, null should be passed in.

        Parameters:
        listener - The EngagementListener that wants to receive events.

      • setHandDetectionListener

        public void setHandDetectionListener(HandDetectionListener listener)
        Sets a HandDetectionListener that the GestureDeviceManager can send hand detection events to. HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent for more information.

        If null is passed in, hand detection events will not longer be sent to the application. If an application has set a hand detection listener but is no longer interested in receiving events, null should be passed in.

        Parameters:
        listener - The HandDetectionListener that wants to receive events.

      • setSwipeListener

        public void setSwipeListener(SwipeListener listener)
        Sets a SwipeListener that the GestureDeviceManager can send swipe events to. See SwipeListener.SwipeEvent for more information.

        If null is passed in, swipe events will not longer be sent to the application. If an application has set a swipe listener but is no longer interested in receiving events, null should be passed in.

        Parameters:
        listener - The SwipeListener that wants to receive events.

      • enableTouchInjection

        public void enableTouchInjection(boolean enable)
        Enable touch injection. When this feature is enabled, camera based hand gestures like a swipe left are converted into the equivalent android touch events that applications would receive when a user performs a physical swipe left on the display using the touch system.
        Parameters:
        enable - the enabled flag

      • isCameraGestureSupported

        public static boolean isCameraGestureSupported()
        Checks if is camera gesture supported.
        Returns:
        true, if is camera gesture supported

      • isFeatureSupported

        public static boolean isFeatureSupported(java.lang.String feature)
        Checks if is feature supported. Returns true if the feature is available and false if it is not.
        Parameters:
        feature - The feature string name. 

                    The current features supported are:

            FEATURE_CAMERA_GESTURES
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_NEAR_GESTURE
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_POINTER
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_ENGAGEMENT_DETECTION
            FEATURE_TOUCH_INJECTION
            FEATURE_OVERLAY_SERVICE
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_NEAR_AND_POINTER
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_NEAR_AND_ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_CLICK_AND_DRAG
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_CIRCLE
            FEATURE_GESTUREMODE_HAND_ZOOM
            FEATURE_DIRECT_MODE

        FEATURE_SDK_CAMERA_GESTURES is the same as isCameraGestureSupported()

        Returns:
        true, if specified feature is supported

      • setCameraId

        public void setCameraId(int id)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sets the hardware camera id to access. Valid ids between 0 to Camera.getNumberOfCameras() - 1. Cannot open camera if opened by other applications.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if camera id is supported

      • setCameraSource

        public void setCameraSource(GestureDeviceManager.CameraSource source)
                     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sets the camera frame source. If this is not set, the default is SOURCE_SYS.
        SOURCE_APP: camera frames are provided from the application
        SOURCE_SYS: camera frames are provided by the framework

        There are currently two options to use the SDK.
        The first is using the default system's GestureDeviceManager.CameraSource.SOURCE_SYS. In this mode, the system sets up the camera and cleans up the resources when the application exits. When the application is in the foreground, it's gesture configuration is the one running. Frames are provided internally. This is the default mode of operation. It is not necessary to initially call this function if the application wants to use the internal gesture system.
        In this mode, the developer may use any of the available gesture modes.

        The second, if available, source is GestureDeviceManager.CameraSource.SOURCE_APP. In this mode of operation, the app must provide camera frames to the gesture system. When the gesture system is in this mode, only GestureMode.ENGAGEMENT_DETECTION is supported. The system will automatically switch to this mode. The app may receive EngagementEvents if a listener is set by calling setEngagementListener(EngagementListener).
        Returns false if camera source is unknown. In this mode, the app must pass frames to the gesture system by calling #onPreviewFrame(byte[], Camera, int, int, int). It is the app's responsibility to setup and release resources.

        To verify that SOURCE_APP is available, query the FEATURE_DIRECT_MODE feature by calling @link isFeatureSupported(String).

        Parameters:
        source - the new camera source
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if camera source is not supported

      • setNotificationIcon

        public void setNotificationIcon(int id)
        Set the small icon resource, which will be used to represent the notification in the status bar. The drawable id must be valid. It is the application's responsibility to pass the correct drawable id.
        If no drawable is set and the system will display the default notification if one is available.
        The drawable icon should match Android's specifications for notification icons.

        Notification icons can be enabled or disabled by calling @link GestureDeviceManager#enableNotificationIcon(boolean).

        Parameters:
        id - A resource ID in the application's package of the drawable to use. Set to 0 to use the default gesture system icon.
        See Also:
        setNotificationIcon(int)

      • getCameraSource

        public GestureDeviceManager.CameraSource getCameraSource()
        Returns the current camera source id.
        Returns:
        the camera source

      • setFrame

        public void setFrame(byte[] data,
            int width,
            int height,
            int cameraOrientation,
            boolean isMirrored)
        Process a preview frame provided from the application.

        The width and height of a preview frame is available by getting the Preview Size from the camera instance. mCameraInstance.getParameters().getPreviewSize() will return the width and height.

        The rotation is the 360 degree orientation angle and be found in the CameraInfo. 

         CameraInfo cameraInfo = new CameraInfo();
 Camera.getCameraInfo(mCameraId, cameraInfo);
 rotationAngle = cameraInfo.orientation;


        Rule: rotate in clockwise direction.

        Front cameras are mirrored. * 

         CameraInfo cameraInfo = new CameraInfo();
 Camera.getCameraInfo(mCameraId, cameraInfo);
 mirrored = cameraInfo.facing == (CameraInfo.CAMERA_FACING_FRONT);
        Parameters:
        data - the data
        width - the image width
        height - the image height
        rotationAngle - the rotation of the camera
        isMirrored - the mirror flag
        Since:
        v2
        See Also:
        android.hardware.Camera.PreviewCallback#onPreviewFrame(byte[], android.hardware.Camera).
